title: 108_hr5310
content: The Act may be cited as the "Ponce de Leon Discovery of Florida Quincentennial Commission Act". The Quincentennial of the founding of Florida by Ponce de Leon in 2013 marks 500 years since his exploration of the state, leading to the naming of Florida as "the land of flowers". Ponce de Leon's search for the "fountain of youth" has become a legendary tale, drawing fame to Florida and the United States, while also inspiring other European countries to explore and settle in the New World. The Quincentennial of the founding of Florida by Ponce de Leon in 2013 commemorates the arrival in Florida and the beginning of colonization, aiming to enhance public understanding of its impact on US history and provide lessons on exploration and discovery. The National Commission on the Quincentennial of the discovery of Florida by Ponce de Leon was established under section 4(a) of the Act. The term "Commission" refers to this entity, while "Governor" refers to the Governor of Florida, and "Quincentennial" signifies the 500th anniversary of the discovery. The National Commission on the Quincentennial of the discovery of Florida by Ponce de Leon is established to plan and conduct the commemoration. It consists of 10 members appointed by the President based on recommendations from Senate and House leaders. The Commission members are chosen based on recommendations from the Governor, the Director of the National Park Service, and the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. They must demonstrate public service, professional expertise, scholarship, and abilities. Appointments must be made within 60 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve for the life of the Commission. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers. The Commission's powers are not affected by vacancies, which are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The initial meeting must be held within 30 days of all members being appointed, and annual meetings are called by the co-chairpersons. A quorum for decision making is 5 members, with the President designating 2 members as co-chairpersons. SEC. 5. DUTIES. The Commission is tasked with planning and developing activities to commemorate the Quincentennial, including projects by Federal departments and agencies. They are also required to consult with various entities to organize and participate in activities related to the history and discovery of Florida. The Commission is responsible for planning activities related to the history and discovery of Florida, including coordinating events nationally and internationally. They must submit a comprehensive report to the President and relevant congressional committees within one year of the Act's enactment. The Commission must submit a comprehensive report with specific recommendations for the allocation of responsibilities and commemoration activities for the Quincentennial, including producing educational materials and organizing related events. The Commission is responsible for various commemoration activities for the Quincentennial, including bibliographical projects, conferences, development of programs for libraries and museums, ceremonies, artistic works, and programs focusing on the discovery of Florida. The Commission is responsible for commemorative activities for the Quincentennial, including issuing coins, medals, certificates, and stamps. They must submit annual and final reports on their activities, programs, expenditures, and donations to the President and relevant congressional committees by December 31, 2013. The Commission for the Quincentennial must consult with federal departments, including the Department of the Interior, and coordinate with Spain for information exchange and research. The Commission for the Quincentennial has powers outlined in Section 6. The Commission for the Quincentennial may provide for the preparation, distribution, and sale of historical materials, competitions and awards for various works related to the Quincentennial, a calendar of programs, and a central clearinghouse for information coordination. The Commission for the Quincentennial may appoint advisory committees as necessary to carry out the purposes of the Act, including the design and designation of logos, symbols, or marks for the Quincentennial commemoration. SEC. 7. ADMINISTRATION. The Commission's principal office is in St. Augustine, Florida, with a possible satellite office in Washington, D.C. The co-chairpersons can appoint a director and deputy director without following civil service laws. The Commission may delegate powers to the director for efficient operation. Staff can be paid from federal funds. The Commission may use federal funds to appoint up to 4 additional staff members and non-federal funds for more personnel. Members serve without compensation but can claim travel expenses. The Commission can appoint staff members and set their compensation without following certain regulations. The Commission can appoint staff members with pay rates capped at specific levels based on the Executive Schedule under title 5, United States Code. The Commission can appoint staff members at pay rates based on the Executive Schedule under title 5, United States Code. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. The Commission may procure supplies using other revenues and expenditures. The Commission has the authority to procure supplies, services, and property, enter contracts, and expend funds. They can also solicit, accept, use, and dispose of donations, with limitations on the value of donations from individuals and non-individuals. The Commission, a nonprofit organization, can acquire items related to the discovery of Florida and deposit them in libraries or museums for preservation. They are also authorized to use postal services. The Commission, a nonprofit organization, can use postal services and accept voluntary services as needed. The Secretary of the Interior is required to conduct a study to assess the feasibility of designating an area in Florida as a National Park to commemorate Ponce de Leon's discovery. A report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations must be submitted to the Senate and House Committees within 3 years of funding availability. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations up to $250,000 for fiscal years 2005 through 2013 is provided by this Act, with funds remaining available until December 31, 2013. The authority granted by this Act will end on December 31, 2013.
